Introduction

Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a blood-borne pathogen and a significant global health concern, with an estimated 58 million people worldwide with chronic HCV.  As an enveloped, single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Flaviviridae family, HCV primarily targets hepatocytes.  Infection leads to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, cirrhosis, and an increased risk for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

Epidemiology and transmission



Chronic HCV infection affects approximately 1% of the global population.  Following acute HCV infection, 20%-50% of individuals spontaneously clear the virus.  The remaining 50%-80% develop chronic HCV infection.  Approximately 20% of chronically infected individuals eventually develop cirrhosis.  Among those who develop cirrhosis, there is a 1.5% chance per year of developing HCC (

figure 1
).



There are at least 6 major HCV genotypes, each with multiple subtypes.  Transmission occurs most efficiently through percutaneous exposure to infected blood.  Key routes include:



  • Injection drug use:  Sharing of contaminated needles and syringes is the most common transmission route in resource-rich countries.
  • Blood transfusions and organ transplants:  Before the widespread screening of blood products, transfusions were a significant source of infection.
  • Health careâ€“related exposures:  Such exposures include needlestick injuries, inadequate sterilization of medical equipment, transmission via hemodialysis, and unsafe injection practices.
  • Sexual transmission:  This route of transmission is less common but higher among individuals with multiple partners, HIV coinfection, or men who have sex with men.  Barrier precautions are unnecessary for monogamous serodiscordant couples because the risk for sexually transmitted HCV infection is <0.1% in this population.
  • Perinatal transmission:  This occurs from an infected mother to her newborn, with a transmission risk of 2%-5%.  Factors increasing this risk include HIV coinfection and high HCV viral load.
  • Other routes:  Sharing personal items such as razors or toothbrushes contaminated with blood, unregulated tattoos (eg, in prison), and body piercings can result in HCV transmission.

Pathogenesis



Lifecycle



HCV primarily infects hepatocytes but can also replicate in lymphocytes and other cells.  The virus enters host cells by binding to surface receptors, followed by endocytosis.  After uncoating, HCV releases its positive-sense, single-stranded RNA genome into the cytoplasm.  The viral RNA is then translated by host ribosomes into a single large polyprotein.  This polyprotein is cleaved by host and viral proteases, including HCV protease, into individual functional viral proteins necessary for viral replication and assembly.



HCV uses its own RNA-dependent RNA polymerase to replicate its genome, producing new viral RNA strands.  This enzyme lacks proofreading 3â€²â†’5â€² exonuclease activity, leading to a high mutation rate and rapid genetic variations.  The viral protein NS5A plays a crucial role in viral replication and assembly, although its mechanisms are not fully understood.  Newly assembled virions are then released from the host cell to infect additional cells.



Antigenic variation



Because of the high mutation rate, numerous quasispecies of HCV develop within infected individuals, allowing the virus to evade host immune responses.  As host antibodies target specific quasispecies, those strains may be eliminated, but new variants emerge to replace them.  This continuous antigenic variation (

figure 2
), particularly in envelope glycoproteins and other viral epitopes, complicates vaccine development and prevents the establishment of lifelong protective immunity.



Immune response



In approximately 80% of infected individuals, the immune system fails to clear the virus, and the infection becomes chronic (ie, chronic viral hepatitis).  Continuous immune activation leads to inflammation (steatohepatitis), and sustained inflammation activates hepatic stellate cells, triggering fibrogenesis.  Fibrosis can eventually progress to cirrhosis, which, over time, predisposes individuals to HCC.  Spontaneous clearance of the virus following acute infection occurs in approximately 20% of infected individuals and is not associated with an increased risk for chronic liver disease.

Clinical presentation

Acute infection



Often asymptomatic (~80% of cases).  When symptoms occur, they can develop 2-26 weeks after exposure (mean onset of 7-8 weeks) and may include jaundice, fatigue, malaise, anorexia, nausea/vomiting, right upper quadrant pain, and low-grade fever.



Laboratory findings:



  • Elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels are often 10-20 times the upper limit of normal.
  • HCV RNA can generally first be detected within days to 8 weeks following exposure.
  • Anti-HCV antibodies take 2-6 months to appear.

Chronic infection



Often asymptomatic.  Nonspecific symptoms include fatigue, abdominal symptoms (eg, nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain), myalgia and arthralgia, weight loss, and neuropsychiatric symptoms (eg, depression, anxiety).  Extrahepatic manifestations (eg, renal disease, skin lesions) are discussed in the section on complications.



Laboratory findings:



  • ALT and AST levels vary.  Up to one-third of patients have normal ALT levels.  Mild elevations are common; only about 25% have ALT levels more than twice the upper limit of normal.  There is a poor correlation between aminotransferase levels and the extent of liver damage.
    • HCV RNA levels and anti-HCV antibodies remain persistently elevated.
    • Thrombocytopenia is due to immune-mediated mechanisms or, if cirrhosis is present, is due to splenic sequestration.

Diagnosis



HCV has a long presymptomatic phase that can last decades.  Untreated infection increases the risk for cirrhosis and HCC, but effective treatment can lower the risk for complications.  HCV is therefore an ideal candidate for an organized screening program.  Routine, one-time HCV screening is now recommended for all adults, augmenting earlier focus on high-risk groups (eg, those born between 1945 and 1965, individuals with HIV, or on chronic hemodialysis).

Serologic testing



Screening for HCV is performed primarily using HCV antibody testing; a positive test indicates 1 of the following (

figure 3
):



  • Active infection:  This infection can be either acute or chronic.
  • Past infection:  The virus has been cleared, but antibodies remain.
  • False-positive result:  This result can occur due to cross-reactivity with other viral antigens or the presence of autoimmune disorders, such as lupus or rheumatoid arthritis.


A negative anti-HCV test usually rules out HCV infection.  However, if the exposure was recent, there may not have been enough time for antibodies to develop.  In such cases, an HCV RNA test is recommended to detect the virus directly, or the antibody test can be repeated after a few weeks.



If anti-HCV antibody testing is positive, confirmatory testing is performed via PCR testing for HCV RNA (

figure 4
):



  • Positive test confirms active infection.
  • Negative test:  indicates either a resolved infection or false-positive antibody test.


PCR testing can be either qualitative (used to diagnose) or quantitative (measures viral load, important for treatment monitoring) (

Imaging and biopsy



Imaging (eg, ultrasonography, CT scan, MRI) is not used for diagnosing HCV but can help assess its complications, such as cirrhosis and HCC.  Advanced imaging techniques such as elastography can noninvasively evaluate liver fibrosis by measuring liver stiffness.



Biopsy is not needed to diagnose HCV, but histologic findings include:



  • Acute HCV (
    image 1
    ):  panlobular lymphocytic infiltration and features of hepatocyte injury (eg, ballooning degeneration, necrosis, apoptosis [Councilman bodies])
  • Chronic HCV (
    image 2
    ):  portal tract lymphocytic infiltration, including lymphoid follicles; fibrosis progressing to cirrhosis with bridging fibrous septa and regenerative nodules

Further evaluation



Once the diagnosis of HCV has been confirmed, patients should undergo further evaluation to determine candidacy for treatment with antiviral agents (discussed in the management section).  This often involves noninvasive tests (eg, laboratory tests, elastography) to assess the extent of liver fibrosis and, sometimes, HCV genotype testing.

Management



The goals of therapy include achieving a sustained virologic response (SVR)â€”defined as undetectable HCV RNA 12 weeks after completing treatment (equating to a cure)â€”halting or reversing fibrosis, and reducing the risk for complications (eg, HCC).  All patients with HCV should ideally be treated with antiviral therapy.

Antiviral therapy



Treatment of chronic HCV infection involves direct-acting antiviral (DAA) agents, which target specific enzymes in the HCV life cycle to inhibit viral replication and assembly:



  • RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibitors (eg, sofosbuvir) inhibit the viral RNA polymerase responsible for replicating the viral genome.
  • Protease inhibitors (eg, simeprevir) prevent the cleavage of the viral polyprotein into functional proteins by inhibiting HCV protease.
  • NS5A inhibitors (eg, ledipasvir) target the NS5A protein, which is crucial for viral replication and assembly.


DAAs have revolutionized HCV treatment, leading to SVR rates exceeding 97%.  Treatment duration is typically 8-12 weeks, after which confirmation of SVR should be performed with HCV RNA testing.  Older medications such as interferon-alpha and ribavirin are no longer routinely used, given their much lower cure rates (50%-80%) and high incidence of adverse effects, including flu-like symptoms and neuropsychiatric effects (interferon-alpha) and teratogenicity (ribavirin).  Antiviral therapy does not prevent future reinfection, and patients should be counseled about this ongoing risk.

Special considerations



  • Pregnancy:  Ribavirin is highly teratogenic.  There is insufficient data to determine the safety of DAAs and interferon-alpha during pregnancy.  Therefore, treatment is generally deferred until after delivery.  In addition, HCV infection does not affect the mode of delivery (ie, vaginal vs cesarean).
  • Breastfeeding:  Breastfeeding does not increase HCV transmission risk to the infant.  Therefore, it is contraindicated only if the nipples are actively bleeding.
  • Exposed infants:  In cases of suspected vertical transmission, antibody testing should be postponed until the infant is 18 months old to avoid detecting maternal antibodies that crossed the placenta.
  • Vaccination:  Patients with chronic HCV should be immunized against hepatitis A and B viruses, if not already immune, because coinfection can lead to severe hepatic failure.  The inactivated hepatitis A and B vaccines are both safe to administer during pregnancy.

Occupational exposure



The risk for HCV seroconversion following an occupational needlestick injury is about 2%.  Unfortunately, no preexposure or postexposure prophylaxis is available.  Immediate baseline testing (<48 hr) with an anti-HCV antibody assay is recommended.  If the results of the baseline testing are negative, the individual should undergo follow-up testing after a specified interval to rule out seroconversion.  Options include:



  • Qualitative HCV RNA:  Because this is usually detectable within days to weeks of exposure, testing is typically performed >3 weeks following exposure.
  • Anti-HCV antibody:  Seroconversion may take months following exposure.  Therefore, repeat antibody testing is typically performed >6 months following exposure (with a positive result also confirmed by qualitative HCV RNA).

Complications



Hepatitis C infection can lead to significant complications, primarily affecting the liver but also causing systemic issues.

Hepatic complications



  • Cirrhosis:  Chronic HCV infection causes ongoing inflammation and liver cell damage, leading to fibrosis and cirrhosis in 5%-30% of chronically infected individuals.  Complications of cirrhosis are discussed in more detail in separate articles.
  • HCC:  Patients with both chronic HCV and cirrhosis have an elevated risk for HCC.  The risk is particularly high in those with advanced fibrosis or cirrhosis (
    figure 5
    ).  HCV infection in the absence of cirrhosis is not a significant HCC risk factor (unlike hepatitis B, discussed in a separate article).

Extrahepatic complications



  • Mixed cryoglobulinemia syndrome:  HCV can trigger the production of cryoglobulinsâ€”immunoglobulins that precipitate at cold temperaturesâ€”leading to vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels.  This manifests as palpable purpura, arthralgia, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy.
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda (
    image 3
    ):  This disease is associated with HCV infection and characterized by photosensitive skin lesions (due to decreased activity of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase).  Patients develop fragile skin with blisters and bullae on sun-exposed areas, particularly the dorsal hands.
  • Lichen planus (
    image 4
    ):  A  chronic inflammatory condition affecting skin and mucous membranes, lichen planus is characterized by pink-purple, itchy, flat-topped papules.
  • Renal disease:  HCV can cause kidney disorders such as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis due to immune complex deposition, leading to proteinuria, hematuria, renal insufficiency, and hypertension.
  • Lymphoproliferative disorders:  There is an increased risk for certain lymphomas, especially non-Hodgkin B-cell lymphoma, due to chronic immune stimulation.


Effective antiviral therapy not only clears the virus but also reduces the risk for these complications.  Early detection and treatment are crucial to preventing long-term morbidity and mortality associated with hepatitis C infection.

Prevention



No vaccine is available for HCV due to high genetic variability and rapid mutation rates.  Risk reduction strategies include:



  • Harm reduction for injection drug users (eg, needle exchange programs, opioid substitution therapy)
  • Public education (eg, awareness of transmission risks)
  • Health care precautions (eg, needle precautions)
  • Blood safety (eg, rigorous screening of blood donations since 1992)
  • Perinatal transmission prevention (eg, screening during pregnancy) (cesarean delivery does not decrease the risk for vertical transmission)

Summary



Hepatitis C virus infection poses a significant global health challenge due to its high prevalence, asymptomatic nature, and potential to progress to serious complications such as cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.  The advent of highly effective direct-acting antivirals, which achieve cure rates exceeding 97%, has made early detection and treatment essential.  Therefore, routine one-time screening for all adults is recommended to facilitate timely intervention and prevent disease progression.  Despite the lack of vaccination, preventive measures such as harm-reduction strategies and safe medical practices remain crucial.
